poem:
The Flute's Return

In Sydney's alleys, a soul adrift,  
cradling dreams of silver breath.  
A melody lost, in the hands of chance,  
its notes echoing the unfilled void.  
Yet amidst the noise, a stranger's grace  
finds the wandering tune,  
and Greensleeves whispers  
a rejoined path,  
as kindness breathes life anew.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The kindness of strangers: I thought I’d lost my flute for ever, then a chance to play Greensleeves returned it to me I was 21, living in Sydney, working as a glassie at a local pub and feeling a bit lost. I didn’t know what to do in life – the one thing I had going for me was playing the flute. I’d saved for two years to buy my flute when I was 16". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
